name: Postgres.app 2.1
body:
Upgrade to the latest maintenance releases of PostgreSQL!

This is the latest and greatest version of Postgres.app for Macs running macOS 10.10 or later. It includes three versions of PostgreSQL:

- PostgreSQL 10.0 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/static/release-10.html)) with PostGIS 2.4.0
- PostgreSQL 9.6.5 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/release-9-6-5.html)) with PostGIS 2.3.3
- PostgreSQL 9.5.9 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/release-9-5-9.html)) with PostGIS 2.2.5

The SHA-256 hash of the disk image is aac88f5072ae8b93d32e0530c08da0c0e361324e9217dfcd15d2bd06f762387c

name: Postgres.app Legacy 10rc1
body:
This is the legacy version of Postgres.app for computers running macOS 10.7 or later. This release has the old user interface and contains a single version of PostgreSQL. We provide this binary so users who don't want to upgrade their Mac can still use up to date versions of PostgreSQL.

This release contains:
- PostgreSQL 10rc1
- PostGIS 2.4.0rc1

name: Postgres.app 2.1beta1
body:
This release of Postgres.app contains the first beta version of PostgreSQL 10!

It also contains PostgreSQL 9.5 and 9.6 so you can try PostgreSQL 10 alongside your existing databases.

- PostgreSQL 9.6.3 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-6-3.html)) with PostGIS 2.3.2
- PostgreSQL 9.5.7 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-5-7.html)) with PostGIS 2.2.5
- PostgreSQL 10beta1 (without PostGIS)

To try PostgreSQL 10, download the ZIP file, expand it, and drag Postgres.app to your Applications folder. Then create a new server in the sidebar, choosing version 10.

The SHA-256 hash of the ZIP file is 7da235acaa0008c998f59a4c1da55b3f921b75f37e05b42883dd4756d2447851

name: Postgres.app 2.0.3
body:
Upgrade to the latest maintenance releases of PostgreSQL!

This is the latest and greatest version of Postgres.app for Macs running macOS 10.10 or later. It includes two versions of PostgreSQL:
- PostgreSQL 9.6.3 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-6-3.html)) with PostGIS 2.3.2
- PostgreSQL 9.5.7 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-5-7.html)) with PostGIS 2.2.5

This release also contains two bugfixes:
- Changed menu icon to use native light/dark mode #385 (thanks to @NickSturgeon)
- Fixed race condition at automatic server start #386 (thanks to @9mm)

The SHA-256 hash of the disk image is a58cd86b3438c60055b98c607c5acb929082bb6bd9a6af92c240624c247655aa

name: Postgres.app 2.0.2
body:
Upgrade to the latest maintenance releases of PostgreSQL!

This is the latest and greatest version of Postgres.app for Macs running macOS 10.10 or later. It includes two versions of PostgreSQL:
- PostgreSQL 9.6.2 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-6-2.html)) with PostGIS 2.3.2
- PostgreSQL 9.5.6 ([Release Notes](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-5-6.html)) with PostGIS 2.2.5

In addition, this release also contains minor UI tweaks:
- configuration files are no longer opened in TextEdit (to avoid typographic quotes) #368
- the elephant menu now contains "show preferences" and "check for updates" commands #373

name: Postgres.app 2.0.1
body:
This is the official release of the all new Postgres.app!

Feature highlights include:
- all new UI
- automatic updates
- run multiple servers simultaneously

The following versions of PostgreSQL are included inside the package:
- PostgreSQL 9.6.1 (with PostGIS 2.3.1)
- PostgreSQL 9.5.5 (with PostGIS 2.2.4)

Postgres.app 2.0 requires macOS 10.10 or later.

Version 2.0.1 fixes a crash on macOS 10.10.

name: PostgresApp 2.0
body:
This is the first official release of the all new Postgres.app!

Feature highlights include:
- all new UI
- automatic updates
- run multiple servers simultaneously

The following versions of PostgreSQL are included inside the package:
- PostgreSQL 9.6.1 (with PostGIS 2.3.1)
- PostgreSQL 9.5.5 (with PostGIS 2.2.4)

Postgres.app 2.0 requires macOS 10.10 or later.

There have been no changes since Postgres.app 2.0 Beta 4 except for dropping the "beta" label.

name: PostgresApp 2.0 Beta 4
body:
This beta 4 update of Postgres.app includes the following features:
- bugfix for Stop button #362 (thanks to @ultimate-deej)
- better error handling when initialising new servers
- new server settings popover

This build includes PostgreSQL 9.6.1 (with PostGIS 2.3.1) and PostgreSQL 9.5.5 (with PostGIS 2.2.4).

This build also includes libpgport and libpgcommon, two static libraries required for building extensions. This should fix and #358 and #360.

Let us know what you think by commenting on issue #350!

Postgres.app 2.0 is written in Swift 3 and requires macOS 10.10 or later

body:
fix bug with plv8 (issue #240)
 fix problem with initdb when language/region settings in system preferences don't match (issue #237)

name: Postgresapp 9.4.0.0
body:
This version contains **PostgreSQL 9.4.0**

Release Notes: http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/release-9-4.html

Note: unlike the release candidate, this version is built without the ICU patch to ensure compatibility with other PostgreSQL installations.

name: Postgresapp 9.4rc1 (ICU)
body:
This is the first release candidate for PostgreSQL 9.4. The final version will be released in roughly two weeks, assuming that no unfixable bugs are found until then.

This build for the first time includes the [patch from Palle Girgenson](http://people.freebsd.org/~girgen/postgresql-icu/README.html) from FreeBSD for ICU support, which should fix collation (text sorting) issues. Including ICU has increased the download size by 13MB, but text sorting is so fundamental that I see no alternative.

Please test this build extensively -- especially sorting and indices on text columns.

name: Postgres 9.3.5.2
body: This version fixes the menu bar icon when using Yosemite with dark mode turned on.

name: Postgresapp 9.4beta3
body:
Beta 3 of this year's new PostgreSQL version, including OpenSSL 1.0.1h.

**Upgrading from Beta 1 or Beta 2**: The on-disk data format has changed again. To upgrade from Beta 1 or 2, use pg_dump to export your data, then delete the data directory, open Beta 3, and restore your backup.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.5.1
body:
This release changes some aspects of how Postgres.app works under the hood. It also enables server logging. These changes allow much better error messages when something doesn't work as expected.

I hope this change will make it easier to debug issues -- and reduce support requests :)

name: Postgresapp 9.4beta2
body:
Beta 2 of this year's new PostgreSQL version, including OpenSSL 1.0.1h.

**Upgrading from Beta 1:** Please note that the data format in this beta is not compatible with the format from Beta 1. To upgrade from Beta 1, use `pg_dump` to export your data, then delete the data directory, open Beta 2, and restore your backup.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.5.0
body:
Updated to PostgreSQL 9.3.5

Release Notes: http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/release-9-3-5.html

name: Postgresapp 9.3.4.2
body:
- updates OpenSSL to version 1.0.1h to address [the latest catastrophic vulnerability](http://ccsinjection.lepidum.co.jp)
- activity indicator in welcome screen while PostgreSQL is starting up

name: Postgresapp 9.4beta1
body:
This is the first beta version of PostgreSQL 9.4, scheduled to be released later this year.

For a list of things that are new, see [What's new in PostgreSQL 9.4](https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/What%27s_new_in_PostgreSQL_9.4)

This version does not include the OSSP-UUID extension because I didn't get it to build. I'll try to build it in a later version.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.4.1
body: Updates OpenSSL to version 1.0.1g to address the Heartbleed vulnerability.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.4.0
body: Updated PostgreSQL to version 9.3.4.0

name: Postgresapp 9.3.3.0
body: Upgraded PostgreSQL to version 9.3.3 and OpenSSL to version 1.0.1f.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.2.0
body:
This version of PostgreSQL has a lot of very awesome new features.
1. First of all, the name has been changed back to **Postgres.app**. This was possible because I moved the binaries to a new path inside the application bundle. Because a lot of people complained about changed binary paths, Postgresapp now automatically scans profile files like `.profile`, `.bashrc` etc. on startup, and offers to update any outdated `$PATH` settings automatically.
2. Postgres.app can now move itself to the Applications folder automatically. Existing older versions will be renamed.
3. Postgres.app can now start on ports other than the default 5432. Just add a line like `port = 2345` to `postgresql.conf`
4. Postgres now has preferences! Most importantly, you can change the location of the data directory. Because the data directory location has changed a few times in recent versions, Postgresapp now looks for existing data directories on first start, and by default uses that directory subsequently.
5. MAN pages for PostgreSQL are now included again! If your PATH is configured correctly, just type `man psql` etc.

Aside from that, I also refactored and cleaned up some of the code. All of these changes should hopefuly make sure that Postgres.app **just works** in more cases than ever before.

Includes PostgreSQL 9.3.2 and PostGIS 2.1.1.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.2.0 Release Candidate 2
body:
This version of PostgreSQL has a lot of very awesome new features.
1. First of all, the name has been changed back to **Postgres.app**. This was possible because I moved the binaries to a new path inside the application bundle. Because a lot of people complained about changed binary paths, Postgresapp now automatically scans profile files like `.profile`, `.bashrc` etc. on startup, and offers to update any outdated `$PATH` settings automatically.
2. Postgres.app can now move itself to the Applications folder automatically. Existing older versions will be renamed.
3. Postgres.app can now start on ports other than the default 5432. Just add a line like `port = 2345` to `postgresql.conf`
4. Postgres now has preferences! Most importantly, you can change the location of the data directory. Because the data directory location has changed a few times in recent versions, Postgresapp now looks for existing data directories on first start, and by default uses that directory subsequently.
5. MAN pages for PostgreSQL are now included again! If your PATH is configured correctly, just type `man psql` etc.

Aside from that, I also refactored and cleaned up some of the code. All of these changes should hopefuly make sure that Postgres.app **just works** in more cases than ever before.

Please note that the documentation on the postgresapp.com website is currently way out of date. Most importantly, the binary path for this version should be `/Applications/Postgres.app/Contents/Versions/9.3/bin`. I will try to update the docs as soon as I have time.

Note: For now, I was only able to test this version on OSX 10.8 and 10.9.

Includes PostgreSQL 9.3.2 and PostGIS 2.1.1.

Release Candidate 2 fixes issue #162

name: Postgresapp 9.3.2.0 Release Candidate
body:
**Please download [Release Candidate 2](https://github.com/PostgresApp/PostgresApp/releases/tag/9.3.2.0-RC2) instead of this version**

This version of PostgreSQL has a lot of very awesome new features.
1. First of all, the name has been changed back to **Postgres.app**. This was possible because I moved the binaries to a new path inside the application bundle. Because a lot of people complained about changed binary paths, Postgresapp now automatically scans profile files like `.profile`, `.bashrc` etc. on startup, and offers to update any outdated `$PATH` settings automatically.
2. Postgres.app can now move itself to the Applications folder automatically. Existing older versions will be renamed.
3. Postgres.app can now start on ports other than the default 5432. Just add a line like `port = 2345` to `postgresql.conf`
4. Postgres now has preferences! Most importantly, you can change the location of the data directory. Because the data directory location has changed a few times in recent versions, Postgresapp now looks for existing data directories on first start, and by default uses that directory subsequently.
5. MAN pages for PostgreSQL are now included again! If your PATH is configured correctly, just type `man psql` etc.

Aside from that, I also refactored and cleaned up some of the code. All of these changes should hopefuly make sure that Postgres.app **just works** in more cases than ever before.

Please note that the documentation on the postgresapp.com website is currently way out of date. Most importantly, the binary path for this version should be `/Applications/Postgres.app/Contents/Versions/9.3/bin`. I will try to update the docs as soon as I have time.

Note: For now, I was only able to test this version on OSX 10.8 and 10.9.

Includes PostgreSQL 9.3.2 and PostGIS 2.1.1.

This release has a serious bug (#162). Please download [Release Candidate 2](https://github.com/PostgresApp/PostgresApp/releases/tag/9.3.2.0-RC2) instead of this version.

name: Postgresapp 9.3.1.1
body:
- PL/Python should work again
- libjsonc bumped to 0.11
- fixed some code signing issues

If you are upgrading from 9.3.0 or 9.2 make sure you read the release notes for 9.3.1.0

name: Postgresapp 9.3.1.0
body:
- Includes PostgreSQL 9.3.1, PostGIS 2.1.0, latest plv8 (with v8 3.18)
- No more sandboxing. This should fix some issues with Mavericks.
- All libraries are now linked with static paths instead of dynamic paths. This means that Postgres93 must be placed in your Applications folder to work. This should hopefully fix a lot of linking issues and problems with plugins.

Since the app name changed, you'll have to update your `PATH` settings in `.bash_profile` (or wherever you put them)

The data directory has changed (again), it is now `~/Library/Application Support/Postgres93/var`

You can use this release alongside other versions (just make sure to quit one version before opening another). If you want to migrate data from a previous release, I suggest using `pg_dumpall` in the following way:

1) Make sure the old Postgres.app is running
2) create a database dump: `/Applications/Postgres.app/Contents/MacOS/bin/pg_dumpall -h 127.0.0.1 -f databasedump.sql`
3) Quit old Postgres.app, start Postgres93.app
4) Load the dump into the database `/Applications/Postgres93.app/Contents/MacOS/bin/psql -h 127.0.0.1 -f databasedump.sql`

name: Postgresapp 9.3.0.1
body: Fix the "start at login" menu item.

name: Postgres.app 9.2.4.4
body:
- PostgreSQL 9.2.4
- PostGIS 2.1 and 2.0

This build now works again on Lion.

For PostGIS users, it also includes PostGIS 2.0 binaries so you can upgrade to PostGIS 2.1 using the command `ALTER EXTENSION postgis UPDATE TO "2.1.0";`

name: Postgres.app 9.3.0.0
body:
- PostgreSQL 9.3.0
- PostGIS 2.1

Note: PostgresApp 9.3.0.0 will create a new (empty) database. If you want to keep your data from a 9.2 installation, the easiest way is to create a dump of your old database using `pg_dump` before upgrading, and load that dump after upgrading.

name: Postgres.app 9.2.4.3
body:
- Fixes the dylib linking issues.
- Fixes openssl shadowing issue.
- Bundles libtiff and json-c

Includes PostgreSQL 9.2.4 and PostGIS 2.1

This release is also a lot slimmer because it only includes necessary files and executables.

name: Postgres.app v9.3RC1.0
body:
- PostgreSQL 9.3RC1
- PostGIS 2.10
- plv8 (v8 3.18)
